Event: Cheap close proximity touch detection developed
comment: The reliability and cost of optical recognition technology, which adds infrared light to a white backlight to allow the camera to better visualise what is touching (or nearly touching) the screen, could reduce dramatically meaning that it is widely incorporated into touchscreens. This will mean any object or material (e.g. gloved hands) can be used to touch a screen and close proximity could be used instead of actual touch (this could have important hygiene implications in a post-Covid scenario).

While systems like Sony's Xperia Touch already exist, which project an image onto a flat surface that can be interacted with like a touchscreen, they are expensive and don't function as well as a much cheaper standard touchscreen. However, performance of these types of devices is likely to improve alongside reductions in their size and robustness. Touchscreen projectors could allow large screens to be projected onto walls and be integrated into smart devices, allowing them to generate their own interfaces that don't require any surface space.

Haptic effects, beyond simple vibration, such as texture and resistance could be incorporated into touchscreens, providing a much more apparently tactile experience. These effects could be delivered through a combination of pseudo-haptic mechanisms (e.g. visual illusions, vibration and sound effects) and friction or force modulation (e.g. via electrostatic or ultrasonic actuation). This might enable certain touch actions to feel easier or harder to perform and allow for haptic feedback for particular actions (e.g. actions with a safety implication).

Event: Projected screens incorporated into smart speakers and smart devices
comment: Networked smart devices and smart speakers, could incorporate small projectors which enable touchscreens to be projected onto nearby surfaces, enhancing the interface with the user.

Event: Legal issues related to touchscreen distraction resolved
comment: Currently, touchscreens on standalone devices (e.g. smartphones) are legally considered to be distracting devices in relation to driving and other high risk activities (e.g. operating machinery). Touchscreens are an increasingly integral part of many vehicle control interfaces. As automation of operation of vehicles and other equipment increases, it is likely that the use of touchscreens may become more feasible and legally permissible, particularly if touchscreens utilise more effects that are independent of vision (e.g. haptic feedback/guidance).

Issues relating to touchscreens and equipment control, such as those seen in the 2017 USS John S. McCain accident, are accounted for through better training, testing and better safety measures. This allows touchscreens to be used with greater confidence for precise and high risk military tasks.
Standard touchscreens become highly ruggedised, possibly incorporating flexible screens, and commercial-off-the-shelf equipment can be used in most hostile environments.

The cost of manufacturing and integrating small touchscreens reduces to such an extent that they can be made easily integral for many types of inexpensive household equipment, becoming common interfaces and replacing switches and dials in many cases (e.g. most ovens incorporate a touchscreen for operation).

Event: Touchscreens made obsolete by speech-based interfaces
comment: Touchscreens become to be seen as an obsolete technology, as the use of personal assistants driven by speech-based interfaces starts to dominate the operation of most devices.

Event: Multiple user large touchscreen become the norm
comment: It is likely that large touchscreens will need to be accessed by multiple users simultaneously in order to facilitate collaboration. Although there are a number of software and hardware solutions that enable this, often based on breaking the larger screen into separate zones, true interactivity will only be possible between users, when they can all operate a screen freely at the same time (like a giant canvas). This will require these large touchscreens to be able to distinguish between users and deconflict multiple inputs related to commands (e.g. how are simultaneous requests to zoom in and zoom out resolved?). It is possible that commercially available large touchscreens will be developed which enable multiple user touch.

Approaches incorporating object recognition and possibly bioelectric impedance, could allow users to be identified simply by data ascertained by their touch of large screens or objects. This could enable the development of large screens which present bespoke information to users on touch or equipment that only works when its owner is holding it (e.g. firearms).

Large horizontal touchscreens could be integrated with 3D imagery to present interactive 3D displays. These could be used to show terrain or mapping in 3D, which could be manipulated by touch (e.g. changing the view orientation or scale). Such display tables could have a number of operational applications such as supporting military planning and the emergency services.

Large vertical touchwalls could be installed in many offices to facilitate collaborative working. These screens could be transparent when not used (e.g. internal windows) but become opaque when being used. Such touchwalls would probably be capable of either presenting one large image or be capable of being broken down into lots of different smaller images, like an array of screens. These walls would be ideal for use in presentations or workshops.

Large projected images that reliably accept touch as an information input could be commercially developed. This technology would build on some of the prototype touch projectors being developed, and deliver a flexible touch display, the size of which could be easily adjusted. This could increase the robustness and portability of large collaborative touch surfaces, because there would be no risk of damage to the screen (e.g. it can't be scratched by users) and there would be no requirement to transport a large screen (the limiting factor would be the size of the projector).

The ability to make any object touch-enabled could be developed through the integration of new materials which allow touch sensors to be applied as a film to the surface of an object. This could reach the stage where the cost of doing this would be relatively trivial and the film is fairly robust and damage resistant. Many low cost devices (e.g. domestic appliances and children's toys) could incorporate this film and the capability to process its input. This might dispense with the requirement for many common interface features such as buttons, switches and dials.

Large touch objects may be adopted across many commercial settings, seeing a substantial acceleration of the trend to incorporate them into fast food outlets. This could see many human-to-human transactional activities, such as paying for items in a shop, replaced by consumers engaging with large touchscreens or displays. Issues to do with touch and hygiene would need to be addressed - possibly, near touch technologies would be incorporated into these interfaces.

Event: Gesture sensing used with AR and VR
comment: Gesture sensing is incorporated into AR and VR technologies, allowing the movements of the user to be read and represented in the virtual environment.

Underlying approaches such as 'time of flight' analysis, structured light patterning and stereoscopic vision offer the opportunity to dramatically improve the fidelity of depth sensing and reduce its cost. This in turn could act as a catalyst for much more sophisticated gesture and movement sensing.

Commercial gaming systems may be developed where gestures or real movements are incorporated into the gameplay, with characters accurately copying user actions, without the requirement for wands or controllers.

Event: Gesture widely used for simple machine control
comment: Simple control of machines and equipment using physical gestures become used more widely. For example, opening doors or turning on a piece of equipment. It may become possible to analyse discrete movements in such a way which allows identity to be verified to very high degrees of confidence. Gesture signatures could also, therefore, be used to fulfil functions such as unlocking doors.

Event: Accurate gait analysis used in identity management
comment: Technologies that are able to identify the unique features of an individual's gait could be used within building management or intrusion detection systems.

Event: A universal lexicon of gestures is developed
comment: A number of large scale physical gestures are developed that are adopted across different applications, similar to double clicking with a mouse or the zoom gesture on touchscreens.

Event: Defence equipment fitted with gesture sensors
comment: Various defence equipment is enabled with gesture reading sensors to allow silent commands to be issued via hand signals (e.g. the directing of nano drones for tactical surveillance).

AI interpretation of physical gestures becomes sufficiently advanced that it equals, or even supersedes, a human's ability to 'read' body language. AI assistants are able to analyse non-verbal cues and utilise this information to deliver their services.

Event: Sensors read multiple users' gestures simultaneously
comment: Gesture sensors become capable of reading multiple individuals' gestures simultaneously, recognising the identity of those making the gestures and interpreting the commands issued accordingly.

Event: Gesture and movement sensors begin to analyse intent
comment: As reading the movements, gestures and physical posture of groups of individuals becomes possible, predictive analytics are used to anticipate the behaviour of people, making probabilistic judgements about whether they might be hostile or whether their mood is changing as a group.

Event: Super resolution massively improves imaging quality
comment: Processing of multiple images, either taken from separate devices or from multiple cameras in the same device, will enable previously poor quality images to be reconstructed routinely as much higher definition images. Deep learning approaches may enable poor quality images taken under poor image capture conditions to be reconstructed as high definition reimagined images, facilitating image recognition under a much wider range of contextual settings.

Event: Facial recognition becomes most common way of verifying identity
comment: Machine-based facial recognition is widely adopted as the gold standard for verifying ID in situations where the individual is physically present or has a device with them. This has a profound impact on the requirement for identity documentation.

Event: Legal regulation of facial recognition toughens
comment: Legal restrictions are imposed on the use of facial recognition technologies in many Western democracies (particularly the EU), whereas its use by government and industry is much less limited in more authoritarian countries. Strict codes are drawn up prohibiting non-consensual use of the technology across Europe and the US, extending existing biometric data protection laws.

Event: General machine recognition surpasses human ability
comment: Deep learning approaches to image analysis mean that machine image recognition becomes better than human abilities in most general settings.

Reading of human emotions through analysis of facial expressions by machines becomes significantly more reliable. This means that personal assistants will be able to interpret the mood of their users and tailor services accordingly.

Event: Image recognition provides reliable threat detection
comment: Systems that allow a wide variety of threats (human-based and from other sources) to be detected in diverse and complex contexts (e.g. busy urban environments) become reliable enough to be trusted instead of human lookouts.

Event: Interpretation of diagnostic imaging entirely automated
comment: Almost all high stakes imagery analysis in fields like medical imaging, mechanical diagnostics and physical exploration removes the human expert from the process. Due to advances in the reliability of the analysis humans could become seen as an inferior option for such tasks.

Event: Image recognition facilitates richer AR experiences
comment: Improved image recognition allows AR applications to develop a much better picture of what is present in the real world and to create experiences which blend with this environment.

Event: Handheld scanners used for health checks
comment: Handheld devices could be much more widely utilised by people at home, and could assist with telemedicare, virtual doctor consultations or general healthcare awareness. Devices can already record body stats, reading temperature, blood pressure and breathing capacity. Advancements in other readings could include handheld image scans for diagnostic purposes.

Event: Devices used widely in a medical setting
comment: Handheld devices could be used by medical practitioners, including devices that can sanitise areas and objects and then provide assessments of their hygiene. Portable X-Ray scanners could also be used by practitioners when visiting patients in their home, alleviating pressures on hospital and dental resources.

The requirement to improve GPS capabilities is likely to drive advances. The main functional requirements include reducing the size and power consumption, improving usability and the longevity of the device in a single session. Military requirements include greater consumption of code, e.g. detailing targets and degree of accuracy, as well as anti-jamming and anti-spoofing capabilities.

The use of handheld devices in the workplace could increase, particularly devices that provide sensory readings or feedback loops. For example, critical infrastructure environments that need sensors to provide readings in real-time. Nuclear power stations, other energy providers and transportation stakeholders will wish to consolidate these readings into large data warehouses,with response teams allocated accordingly. Devices will need to be damage-resistant and have solid-state-drives (SSDs) to ensure that data integrity is maintained.

Event: Ubiquity of devices in supply chains
comment: In order to reduce wastage, optimise manufacturing turn-around times and ensure safety/quality checks, handheld devices will become even more common in supply chains. Devices that can provide readings on targets, using statistics pulled from large data warehouses are likely to become increasingly common. Centrally managed data systems should feed information in real-time, streamlining production and manufacturing chains.

Event: IoT devices for household energy or security settings
comment: Handheld devices that enable homeowners to control household settings, including light, heating and security devices could become much more commonplace. Household equipment would need to be configured to receive and process requests from the handheld devices via the internet.

Payment dockers that can scan chips embedded in the hand are likely to be used to reduce attempts of card fraud and identity theft. This will be dependent on the development of chips with very low rejection rates and also on societal adoption.

The combination of VR headsets with video projectors could enable users to use holographic keyboards, removing the requirement for a physical keyboard device. This requires advancements between data exchange between VR headsets and projectors, to ensure that the user interactions are captured in real-time with low latency.

Event: Interactive keyboards with autocorrect and predictive text functions
comment: There have been considerable advancements in software applications for autocorrect and predictive text functions, but this could be extended to simulated keyboards (holographic, gesture and other forms of movement).Predictive models would have to consider a wide range of input parameters, including multilingual texts, character usage, colloquial phrases and common abbreviations. Feedback mechanisms to improve this feature would be required from the user.

Machine learning (ML) algorithms would require large database systems and models would have to be robust to provide high accuracy levels. The user could guide the keyboard to input, to correct and to format the text via voice commands. This would require the keyboard to have a microphone functionality using Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques. Currently, these are not as reliable in accurately processing speech and there are use cases for improving the technology further.

Keyboards with movement sensors could process text inputs with gestures using a visual dashboard, whiteboard or general screen. For users that have a hand impairment, the use of gesture control would be extremely useful. For general users the convenience of using gestures could save time compared to manual text inputs.

Keyboards with rotational movements have been developed and are an alternative to the traditional keyboard layout. The user must rotate two mouse-like devices that are separated on two mats. By rotating clockwise or anti-clockwise the user is provided with an interface that displays the selected letters and characters, by clicking the mouse the selection of a character is confirmed. The usability of these devices could increase, boosting their adoption.

Simulated keyboards would use holographic video or image projectors. The advancement of 4D holograms would improve the user experience by simulating a real keyboard. Additionally, using simulated keyboards would reduce desk space and wastage of resources as a physical device is no longer required. Improvements to the image projector technology and to the method in which text inputs are captured from users will be required.

Event: Security features to combat compromise risks
comment: Any technologically enhanced keyboard has the risk of becoming compromised. The risks are greater with keyboards as they are the standard approach for enabling text inputs into machines. Users are reliant on keyboards to verify their identity, to access systems and to use services on a given machine. Cyber adversaries may take advantage of the keyboards that have enhanced connectivity by remotely accessing them. Additionally, keystroke attacks could monitor and match the patterns of the keyboard by the user. Other attacks could be developed to exploit the underlying Machine Learning (ML) algorithms that are used in predictive texting. These security risks should be considered in the design stage for keyboards or text-input devices.

Rugged, flexible keyboards could be used in military settings as a back-up system if other communication systems fail or are destroyed in combat. Wearable armbands could enable the user to input their location, request back-up or send an SOS signal and provide critical status updates on missions or casualties. These devices could be constructed from pliable materials.

Event: Digital pens and impaired hand movement
comment: Users that have impaired hand movements, such as those suffering from a stroke or Parkinsons, could benefit from digital pens that can correctly identify handwriting strokes from the movement in the hand. Currently there are plans to develop pens that can be used as an early warning indicator system for the development of Parkinson's disease or other neurological diseases. Digital pens would require sensors to capture both the hand and wrist movements.

Currently, interactive whiteboards are used in classroom and business settings. Tablets act like notepads with drawing and writing applications that can be used with interactive pens. Advancements for interactive notepads and whiteboards include capturing notes as still images and importing as post-it notes or editable notes.

The discovery of graphene has fuelled the development of e-paper prototypes and has advanced current e-notebooks and e-readers. Graphene is a carbon material that is well suited for electronic writing or drawing devices. It is extremely strong, with high electrical conductivity, natural mechanical flexibility and enhanced optical displays. Graphene e-paper prototypes are paper-like and can be bent or folded. Graphene is expensive, costing $100 per gram making current prototypes expensive and unmarketable. The reduction in cost of these devices could dramatically increase adoption rates.

Event: Remotes or lasers with writing capabilitites
comment: Users that have impaired hand movements, such as those suffering from a stroke or Parkinson’s, could benefit from remote devices that can draw or write on their behalf, particularly if using an interactive pen is not an option. The remotes or lasers could beam a small and thin light to the display which captures the intended movement.

Event: Object design software for 4D prinitng technology
comment: 4D printing enables 3D printed objects to transform into another structure via the influence of an external energy or stimulus; for example, temperature or light. Users that can draw and design 4D objects, capturing the stages of its physical shape change would advance the production of 4D printing methods.

Currently, there are realistic prototypes of cameras that are able to visually record and translate video streams of individuals into live 3D holograms. The design of these systems requires advanced interactive drawing capabilities to enhance the hologram matrix shapes. Users may also benefit from applications enabling their drawings to come to life as holograms, which would require additional equipment to stream and project the image as a hologram in the physical space.

Event: Enhanced facial recognition for suspect sketch profiles
comment: Equipment that is used for facial or body profiling of suspects in criminal investigations could be enhanced with facial recognition software. Criminal sketch artists are able to integrate or mould suggested images into their sketch. This could not only save time, but it could also support the successful identification of the suspect, particularly if the algorithm can provide common features or automatically search criminal databases for a suggested match. However, removing inherent biases in the algorithm design would be difficult and controversial if used in a criminal court proceeding.

Event: Eye tracking in retail VR systems adopted
comment: Shopping and travel experiences via VR headsets could benefit from eye-tracking sensors, to capture users interests. Users may be able to proceed payments via eye movements and use retinal scanning to verify identity. Other commercial use cases could be designing road or building signs, improving architectural and road signage designs by tracking spatial awareness.

Event: Eye tracking in VR systems used for military analytics
comment: Eye tracking for military use-cases could benefit the design of tactical VR training systems. Metrics based on visual interaction and awareness are crucial for identifying threats, attacking targets and supporting group missions. For example, metrics on the pattern or frequency of eyes identifying a false target would be an important tool to develop the skills of new military personnel.

In criminal proceedings, eye tracking equipment could be used as evidence against suspects. In military proceedings, any connected visual equipment could be used in a case of crime against humanity or war crimes.

Event: Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs) and road safety
comment: Video image sensors could be added to CAVs to inform drivers whether a pedestrian is aware of traffic. Eye tracking monitors could identify whether pedestrians have complete or peripheral vision of the vehicle, for instances where the pedestrian is unaware, the vehicle could apply emergency braking to avoid vehicle-related injuries. Additionally, eye tracking software could be used in court against injury liability claims.

With interactive visual screens, eye tracking cameras can monitor attention and reaction to advertisements. With retinal scanning, the identification of pedestrians could be possible, enabling marketers to target the advert to the individual's preferences. Tracking perception on products would improve the design of visuals and variants could be tested against different target groups. Purchasing of items could be conducted with visual confirmation, removing the requirement to input payment data. There are ethical implications and the encroachment on personal privacy with the adoption of eye tracking technology for advertising purposes.

Sensors can provide heat maps that capture the frequency and the length of time focused on a specific image point or feature. Eye tracking sensors must capture the iris movement, map the movement against a specific image and record fluctuations in movement based on subsequent stimulus. For example, the observation of a still object that begins to move and confirmation from the user who wishes to view a different image.

Event: Interactive screens or contact lenses and glasses
comment: The integration of interactive screens and eye monitoring cameras/sensors is required in the physical space. Users could also wear contact lenses or smart glasses that feedback eye tracking metrics to a central system. There is a requirement for an accurate and streamlined data exchange between the eye tracking sensors and the backend central system.

Transparency on the methods of storing eye-tracking data would have to be outlined by both the manufacturer and the third-party organisation that uses the technology to provide a specific service. In the case of advertising, EU users would have to consent to data collection as outlined under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which should be anonymised and where the user has the 'right to be forgotten'. There are concerns that eye tracking could be used as a form of government or organisational surveillance, particularly if eye tracking is used to conduct financial transactions.

Dashboard metrics should provide the user (physician or surgeon) with accurate measurements. Algorithms must be able to provide data with considerable precision as any deviations could have consequences on a user or patient. There are many approaches for representing data in a user interface. Designers of these systems would also have to consider how data is stored, updated, retrieved and omitted as part of a large-scale data cleansing process.

Tactical training, whether physical or simulated would require a physiological monitor to record physical reactions. Monitors can be useful in ensuring that health and safety requirements are met during training sessions. For example, an audible or readable alert system.

Mobile health monitors would benefit uses in conflicts and remote search and rescue areas, particularly places that are susceptible to natural disasters. Patients that require immediate assistance would benefit from a mobile monitor that could assess the risk of death, internal bleeding or infection. Metrics could assist physicians in decision making of patient care.

Any alterations to the monitoring system as a form of sabotage may be difficult to identify and to track. If the monitors are used for surgical or medicinal use cases, then this could have significant implications for the patient, particularly if there are any deviations of the metrics or baseline measurements. Updates on the monitors and measurement devices should be centrally managed, but would require an internet connection.

Whole integrated health monitoring systems are likely to be introduced for many people. These systems would use a variety of permanently worn or embedded sensors to provide continual health monitoring for factors such as cardiovascular health, nutrition, optimal activity levels, hormone levels. They could be used by individuals with specific diseases, pregnant women, but increasingly by the general population.

Event: Predictive analytics powering autonomous health interventions
comment: At some point, it is likely that health analytics will reach a sufficient level of sophistication to enable many medical interventions to be delivered without any human involvement in the decision-making process. The array of data gathered from physiological sensors, combined with predictive analytics approaches could enable medicines to be dispensed before individuals experience any symptoms.

Physiological monitors will probably get smaller and smaller. Disposable monitors that are ingested or injected into the blood stream could become common. This could enable much more granular data to be gathered from humans. The use of temporary and disposable monitoring devices may help to allay many privacy concerns.

Event: Force and touch feedback analysis developed
comment: Tactile sensing methods could be carried out with 'force' and 'touch' feedback connections with sensor devices. The VR set would provide the visual stimulus and a physical control device measures the level of interaction. Additionally information on interactions could include angle, frequency of repetitive movements, deviations of normal physical behaviour, such as hand and body movements.
Low cost and flexible gaming rigs might be developed that capture lots of different movements (running, jumping, skiing, pedalling). This could be similar to the Peloton bike, but for multiple uses.

Operational personnel who are wounded or affected by conditions such as strokes would benefit from VR with physical controls. Patients could reduce motor impairment by improving reaction times, physical dexterity and visuals. The combination of using joysticks or smart clothing such as gloves would complement physical control VR systems, particularly for military rehabilitation programmes.

Training of operational personnel in the military would benefit from VR systems that simulate and test users under physical conditions. Data on the success of tactical training methods can be captured and compared against individuals and other groups. Tactical training in VR systems could assess group dynamics and stress levels. This could incorporate more sophisticated multi-directional treadmills or even group equipment.

Event: Interfaces for commercial aviation and holidays
comment: Users who are unable to travel could experience the benefits of travelling without having to leave their homes. VR sets could be another method for the aviation and travel industry to expand their customer base. Additional equipment would be necessary to replicate the physical motion of travelling. This might involve much smaller flight simulation devices.

Users might be able to experience workplace environments, as a way to connect remote workers or to provide a new onboarding experience. This could involve adaptive physical environments, which are able to mimic different workplaces.

The ethical implications of using VR with physical controls is the protection of data. Biometrics and cognitive metrics collected may not be self apparent by the user, but could be exploited by organisations or cyber adversaries for profit. For example, it could collect information about their movement during a game which allows future identity verification measures, based on unique movements, to be circumvented.

The sheer amount of data collected by the VR sets identifies an integration concern. Advanced graphics are necessary to enhance the representation of the physical space. High bandwidth is required to ensure high-quality of image streaming. Data storage increases exponentially with each device and with any additional devices required, such as joysticks and sensors. Integrating with physical interfaces could therefore be limited by these constraints.
Smart patches can be used for identifying sleep disorders and for administering medication. Future examples of smart patches include administering vaccinations.

Smart masks and shields could monitor the level and risk of infection when exposed to or in close proximity to infected individuals. Sensors on particulates in the air could record the time spent in polluted areas and could identify particulates in the air to assess the air quality as well as the risk to lung health.

Smart glasses or mounted head displays will be able to superimpose additional information on the environment. For use in the military, this could include the degree of accuracy on a particular target and level of perceived threat.

Earbuds that could communicate and connect to other military personnel on the ground in real time would support operational tasks. Central military systems could also forward announcements and updated information to ground personnel. These devices would need to be small and very robust.

Event: Smart watches and wristbands extend their function
comment: Watches and wristbands could assist with information exchange, such as sharing business cards, processing payments and passport control. Identity management of users can be verified by additional PIN or passwords controls on devices, utilitising Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). Users would have to trust devices storing Personal Identifiable Information (PII) and redundancy checks on systems would be mandatory to reduce false positive rates.

Sharing biometric information via clothing may be controversial for some. Clothing can monitor and record body metrics, including heart rate, temperature, breathing and movement. With the advancements in sensor technology and connection methods, users are able to receive the data to their smartphones, but there are additional considerations needed if garments are lost or stolen. For families with babies, devices can identify irregularities in sleeping patterns or breathing. For adults, leisurewear can update users of UV rates and air temperature, informing users to avoid sunlight. Other sportswear can update users on the intensity of their workouts and how to improve performance, for example the pronation of feet for runners.

Any device that shares biometric data has to be safe to wear and should be secure to ensure that data isn't stolen. Legislation is required to ensure devices are updated regularly. Manufacturers are responsible for mandating software updates via applications that collect data from sensors. This should be outlined in the terms and conditions of using the product to remove liability.

Voice over 5G New Radio enhances video calling experience as the dependencies requirements on underlying technology is removed. It utilises 5G Stand-Alone (5G) architectures, which enables network slicing. This enhances the callers ability to make multiple calls or video calls simultaneously, with little to no latency issues. Since 2019, advancements in 5G SA has made this possible, but extensions to other communication devices such as connected vehicles or wearable IoT devices could be considered.

There is a requirement to provide telepresence robotics in the future. For example, classrooms, academies and universities could provide virtual lessons with live streaming via robotic devices. This would increase capacity and reduce impact on teaching as a result of staff shortages. Robotics could also replay previously recorded lessons. Telepresence robotics could also be used in business settings, conferences and exhibitions as sensors can track and record presenters. From a military perspective, robotics are already used in bomb disposal activities, other use cases could include remote communication and evidence collection for recording evidence of war crimes.

Event: Personalised telepresence equipment and recording of discussions
comment: Currently, there is a widespread use of personal telepresence equipment, ranging from cameras, microphones and webcam sensors. An advancement in this area could be translating discussions into other languages, particularly for multilingual audiences, international conferences and inter-governmental organisation meetings. Other advancements include documenting spoken discussions in real-time and recording the content in a pdf file, which could be provided to the attendees after the meeting session. Issues around the capabilities of recording and documenting meetings, including the responsibility of data ownership would need to be transparent to consumers.

Event: Immersive telepresence equipment, VR and holograms
comment: Telepresence equipment could benefit from VR devices that could provide a replication of a physical space, such as a conference hall or a business meeting space. Users could create a realistic avatar and converse as they would in reality. Current users can do this with commercial VR sets but the software required to streamline movement in real-time with low latency requires refinement and development. Holograms of individuals via robotics could also be a solution that enables presenters or attendees to replicate their physical body. For example, a meeting room could contain several camera projectors, thus transporting holographic attendees to the room, removing travel requirements.

Interactive equipment that would enable interaction by an attendee could include IoT smart boards and panoramic hosting screens for large scale meetings or conferences. Currently, smart boards and collaborative applications exist that facilitate shared working. Advancements in smart boards could be with VR headsets and sensors that enable editing in real-time as well as offering users a sense of being physically present. Graphene in panoramic screens would also enable users to experience meetings with superior optical quality.

Event: Legislation on prevention of deep-fake images or videos
comment: Currently, deep-fake images and videos are present across social media platforms. In the case of telepresence equipment and streaming providers, the presence of deep fake videos or images is a serious concern. Not only would it damage the reputation of an organisation, streaming provider or telepresence manufacturer, but it would also cause serious distress to consumers. The inability for users to differentiate between a deep-fake image or video would generate numerous potential problems. Therefore, there is a real need for legislation to protect users and to successfully identify manipulation of telepresence equipment to create, disseminate and promote the use of deep-fake images.

There is a requirement for telepresence manufacturers and streaming providers to be transparent on data collection, storage and protection practices. There is a range of data that could be collected from these devices, including geospatial data, facial and voice recognition. Local storage of data may be created on the telepresence device, which if stolen could be compromised. Users’ data should be protected by data privacy legislation. Additionally, new features or updates which prompt a feedback response from users should also be considered.

The maintenance and security management of telepresence equipment must be transparent, particularly regarding their resiliency and robustness against cyber attacks. Data will need to have multiple statuses, data at rest or in transit should be secured with encryption.

Building on existing capabilities that do live translation of speech, capabilities might develop to the extent where these can be relied on to the same extent as human translators. Further, such capabilities could be used to generate highly accurate meeting transcripts. This could be particularly valuable in a military context, where patrolling personnel may come into regular contact with local populations.

Currently, diagnostics and patient consultations are being conducted more frequently online. The use of speech recognition systems could improve the speed and accuracy of diagnostic and selection of treatment. Systems could use Natural Language Processing (NLP) to screen the verbal descriptions of patients when disclosing their symptoms. Algorithms could then provide a series of suggested treatments and Machine Learning capabilities could be applied to improve patient care and monitoring overtime.

The capabilities of using biometrics with speech recognition technology would be advantageous over traditional biometric methods, such as fingerprints. There is a greater accuracy and longevity of a speech record than that of facial or finger print images, which would need updating on a regular basis. For military purposes, access control systems using voice recognition could be a useful alternative for accessing secure buildings, weapons and warehouses.

Event: Advances in speech anayltics and AI/ML
comment: The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) principles in speech analytics will be crucial for commercial industries. For example, advertising could replace current Search Engine Optimisation (SEO) techniques and instead opt for 'Speech Engine Optimisation', which could easily be assimilated with the current device offerings, such as Siri, Google Home and Alexa services. Public concerns are likely to continue relating to mass data collection and data associated with advertising.

Users may be able to confirm payment of purchases with their voice using a secret password, as opposed to a PIN. Although, updating systems with new voice recordings would be problematic, particularly if the recording were intercepted. Additionally, the service would not be suitable for individuals who are mute or who suffer from speech impediments.

Speech patterns could promote improved design of speech systems, including the idea of design-by-inclusivity and ensuring that systems are designed to meet the needs of various user groups. This would enable multiple accents, dialects and language cultures to be provided with services. Patterns could also expand the development of speech systems for other use cases.

Event: Regulating biometrics, security risks and deep fake recordings
comment: Legislation on biometric security and access controls for voice recordings should be a priority. Deep-fake recordings and mimicking voices would be a serious concern, particularly if video imaging is absent and the information exchange is solely reliant on voice. Manufacturers of speech recognition services and streaming service providers would have to be held accountable.

Event: Advancement of ML and AI algorithms
comment: The design of new ML and AI algorithms becomes more robust. Algorithms will be able to handle a plethora of data ingests of a vehicles' environment as well as information on wireless connectivity. Tracking metrics on safety performance will be conducted in real-time. Improved algorithmic performance will directly impact the performance of reaction times, including breaking and acceleration speeds in Connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs).

Event: Advancement of sensor technology for image recognition and eye tracking
comment: Technology that can identify anomalies in image recognition patterns and track eye movement to gauge awareness levels of pedestrians will assist in providing safety assurances.

Event: Battery powered vehicles with long-lasting and high-performing batteries
comment: Current estimations predict that vehicle battery technology will improve, reducing charging time and expanding miles per charge. Evolving technology of lithium batteries will see an upsurge in electronic vehicle offerings and charging capabilities. The main challenge is obtaining investment and skills for R&D for testing and integration of batteries in vehicles. The funding and resources are mandatory to make this technology commercially viable.

A significant challenge is likely to arise to enable the integration of large scale "Smart-City" planning to enable large scale adoption of electrical vehicles, especially "Smart-Grids" to localise battery power charging station docks in cities. This is evident in current planning proposals from Western countries, which aim to replace the majority of petrol vehicles with battery or hybrid-powered vehicles by 2030.

To reduce casualties in tactical warfare and to ensure targets are validated, autonomous systems could replace human operators for many military vehicles and even some weapon systems. This will have profound implications for interfaces, where the emphasis will be on direction and command rather than detailed control. Interfaces may therefore become simpler and less focused on enabling manual dexterity.

Event: Fleet vehicles routinely communicate in tandem
comment: Fleet vehicles will reduce delivery times, gas emissions and vehicle fatalities involving lorries/hauliers by communicating among themselves. The speed limit on fleet vehicles can be set and braking patterns based on sensory or internet communication between lorries. Controls may concentrate on facilitating the flow of information to humans-in-the-loop, rather than supporting direct control of the vehicles.

Event: Road-Side-Units (RSUs) developed to communicate traffic information
comment: The purpose of Road-Side-Units (RSUs) is to enable the rollout of Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CAVs). These systems, potentially utilising edge computing technologies, are likely to change the way drivers interact with their vehicles. They may focus more on engaging with the RSU itself, rather than their own vehicle. These systems have the potential to significantly improve traffic flow. Traffic and weather information can be fed directly to each vehicle whilst travelling across a road system network. This may need to be also communicated to the driver by various display interfaces.

Event: Vehicular ad hoc networks (VANETs) facilitate communication
comment: Vehicular ad hoc networks (VANETs) will have the capability to reduce traffic accidents and fatalities from collisions. Unlike human drivers, VANETs could significantly reduce the reaction time for emergency braking. Sensors at the front of the vehicle and internet communication between other vehicles in the vicinity will trigger a braking reaction. Interface controls are likely to concentrate on allowing these systems to be quickly overruled by a driver if required.

Event: Decommissioning and conversion of petrol engines to hybrid vehicles
comment: The UK government has set a target to ban the selling of petrol and diesel car engines, replacing them with electric, battery powered or hybrid equivalents by 2030. Major constraints include the reliability and availability of electric charging stations, as well as the National Grid's ability to maintain demand. Planning is required to roll-out suitable and cost-effective conversion solutions of combustion engines to hybrid models. Wider concerns include identifying who is responsible to cover the cost of the conversions (consumer, manufacturer or government). Both vehicle controls and information displays may have to prioritise allowing human users to optimise energy efficiency.

Event: Significant legal issues arise relating to accountability
comment: Legislation defining the accountability of vehicle-related deaths of Connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs) is still undefined, as there is a lag between the development of the technology and the passing of laws that protect citizens and consumers. CAVs have caused vehicle-related deaths in the United States, under testing conditions, with errors relating to algorithmic functionality, inadequate sensor recognition and poor emergency braking times. Legislation should be rolled-out on an ongoing basis to coincide with advancements in technology. Ethical concerns include how algorithms make life-and-death decisions, between reducing casualties or ignoring built-in functions, such as keeping within road markings. Software engineers and/or manufacturers may be liable for inaccurate checking and testing of algorithmic functionality.

Legislation defining how vehicle data is collected will be required, if connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs) communicate over the internet. In this case, there will be a requirement to store this data at rest and preparation for transmission. RSUs may have the capacity to log each vehicle with an ID, as part of vehicle monitoring activities. VANETs that communicate with other vehicles will require internet providers to facilitate and enable accurate communication exchange via the internet.

Event: Legal issues of cost decommissioning petrol vehicles
comment: Legislation that specifies the solution type, method and implementation process will be necessary to enable the conversion of combustion engine vehicles into hybrid models. Defining responsibility and testing of conversion models to meet health and safety standards must also be considered. This may significantly accelerate the development of vehicle control interfaces as we rapidly transfer to new technologies.

The use of softer, more organic-like materials in robots is likely to increase. This would enable them not only to take advantage of elastic and deformable materials akin to skin and muscle, thereby supporting more nuanced interactions with objects, but would also make them appear less mechanical. This could have profound effects on the way they are perceived by people. They may begin to look more human, but also feel more human. Touch interactions with robots could seem very difficult if they were generally soft and not cold.

A range of improved interfaces drawing on different sensory modalities are likely to be incorporated into robot design. This would see widespread use of sophisticated and reliable voice control interfaces, and gesture and image recognition technologies employed to allow the robots to respond to complex inputs.

The agility, adaptability and dexterity of robots is currently quite limiting. They struggle to operate in uncontrolled and changing environments and are unable to perform many fine motor skills. However, it is possible that manufacturers and researchers will significantly address many of these issues, bringing robots up to human-levels of skill and precision in many generalisable functions. This could see robots that can walk easily across different terrains, operate hands that can perform a range of complex and delicate tasks and perform dynamic movements requiring great coordination such as catching or striking moving objects. In some instances their ability is likely to surpass human ability.

Robots could become a regular fixture in the work environment. They might be employed to support telepresence activities or be used to provide refreshments or cleaning services. There could be different levels of interaction required for robots, where some might be directed by multiple office occupants (e.g. multiple people requesting refreshments) and others might need to be controlled remotely or could be primarily autonomous (e.g. a cleaning robot). The interfaces would need to reflect this multiple user, versus single or no user concept. There would also need to be ways of verifying user authorities to prevent unauthorised users from controlling a robot. Technologies such as voice recognition or the use of biometric sensors could be required.

The data analytics underpinning the interpretation of human inputs for control of robots could improve dramatically, allowing a range of natural ways of communicating. For example, robots may become capable of interpreting the body language and physical gestures of users and respond accordingly. This would enable robot controller interfaces to move away from more limited and binary approaches (such as handheld controllers) towards much more flexible and expansive interface types such as image or gesture recognition.

Collaborative working with robots could become the norm in some work environments and the safe and precise physical handover of objects being worked upon could become a necessity. It is possible that the ability could be developed for robots and humans to work dynamically alongside one another as flexibly as two humans might.

Event: Robots used widely in care sector
comment: With the growing requirements for care provision for an increasingly elderly population, it has long been mooted that robots will be used to plug some of the gaps in the social care workforce. This could have a transformative effect on society's perception of robots. Using them to provide human care because of necessity, could influence people to consider robots for other important tasks, such as child care. Furthermore, if the primary users of robots are an elderly population, this is likely to drive interface design. Producing interfaces for those with a higher occurrence of sensory impairment and with lower technology skills could drive development towards simpler interfaces.

The miniaturisation of robots could lead to routine availability and use of robots that are too small to touch and see. This means that relying on touch interfaces and feedback of the robot's position and activity via direct sight of the robot will not be an option. Therefore, interfaces will need to somehow provide visual feedback of potentially tiny robots, that could be operating in environments which are too small to position external cameras in. This could mean that virtual reality representation of robots might be required to support their control and direction.

The development of relatively cheap drones and their integration into coordinated swarms could lead to demand for the ability to control multiple robots simultaneously. Due to the limitations of human attentional focus, it is likely that users will be unable to provide explicit control of multiple robots at the same time, especially if they are performing delicate tasks. The control interfaces for multiple robots are therefore going to have to take into account a more abstract level of direction, where commands are issued to a collection of robots and the precise execution of those commands is carried out autonomously. It could be that technologies such as brain-computer interfaces would enable this direction to occur in a more intuitive way.

Ongoing experimentation with exoskeletons and their control via neural sensors may advance to the stage where exoskeletons become a standard tool for the mediation of musculoskeletal injuries. This could lead to the routine use of exoskeletons in rehabilitation, where they are used to train particular movements or provide physical support to injured joints, which could be gradually reduced. Furthermore, they could become as common as wheelchairs, being used to support individuals with long term mobility issues. Central to this expanded use will be the requirement to more reliably and less invasively capture neural signals for control.

Event: Exoskeletons routinely used for manual handling
comment: It may become standard, or even a mandated requirement, to wear an exoskeleton for various manual handling tasks. In particular, lumbar support could become a focus of exoskeleton design. The high incidence of lower back injuries and their cost to organisations may create a substantial market for this type of product. Existing commercially available models will need to reduce in price and increase in comfort and effectiveness to underpin this broader adoption.

One of the key limiting factors in many exoskeleton designs is the simplicity of the joint structure. The organic joints which they support are often more sophisticated and flexible than the robotic equivalents (e.g. using slightly elastic connective tissues or subtle hinge mechanics to operate in complex ways). Matching the natural range of motion and behaviour of the human body and its joints could be achieved through the development of more complex joint designs. This could enable exoskeletons to feel like they are assisting more naturally.

Softer, lighter and more flexible materials are going to be required to be incorporated into exoskeletons if the technology is to move away from its currently bulky designs. These might see exoskeletons which feel more like skin tight garments with lightweight supports being developed. While these types of designs could be useful in supporting the correct alignment of the body during particular tasks, they are unlikely to be able to provide heavy lifting capability. They could still potentially augment human performance though, by adding small gains to capabilities such as muscle power. These exoskeletons could be used to support athletic performance.

At the moment many exoskeletons are controlled by explicit input devices, such as held or touched controls, or rely on fairly crude feedback mechanisms. It is likely that the control of exoskeletons will become increasingly implicit, utilising the reading of neural signals, but also factoring in strain and biomechanical feedback to provide the support that is needed, without any conscious input from the user.

As the use of exoskeletons increases, there will need to be a concomitant increase in the regulation of their production and use. Globally accepted standards could be adopted and maintained by appropriate commercial or occupational organisations. This may restrict uses in certain contexts, but also provide a framework to help manufacturers produce safer designs.

Smaller exoskeletons used to support specific joints or correct specific problems could be developed. For example, dynamic foot supports or orthotics could be developed. Similarly, devices that are designed to support finger movement and perhaps reduce repetitive strain injury or alleviate arthritic pain might be produced by manufacturers. The application of exoskeletons to smaller joint structures would mark a move away from the support of gross motor movements towards fine motor movements. This would necessitate a dramatic increase in the level of precision required by exoskeletons.

Event: Operational exoskeletons deployed by the military
comment: Some of the various exoskeletons currently under development and being trialled by the military could be further developed and eventually deployed in an operational context. These are likely to concentrate on support load bearing dismounted personnel as well as protecting their leg joints from excessive strain. It could be that exoskeletons become standard issue equipment for some personnel, or they may simply be restricted to supporting the injured.

The rapid development of various polymers which do not provoke immune responses when implanted within the human body is likely to continue. This should allow implants to overcome the issue of rejection, removing a potential barrier to this technology.

RFID and NFC implants which enable many contactless capabilities (e.g. contactless payments or opening doors) are already being implanted in early adopter communities. If the capabilities and ease of insertion for these implants increase then the user community is likely to grow. This in turn could also lead to the range of services offered and their integration into our everyday infrastructure to expand. It may be that routine transactions such as opening doors, starting cars, accessing public transport and paying for groceries could all be done via these implants.

Event: Implants draw on human body for power
comment: Implants requiring a power source may come to draw purely on the energy generated by human body movements. By harnessing this kinetic energy many devices could operate without any requirement for recharging, particularly if combined with advances in the development of ultra low energy devices. This self-sufficiency would dramatically enhance the usability of implanted devices.

Event: Augmented vision via bionic eye implants
comment: The sophistication of bionic eye systems, such as the Argus II, could increase substantially. These systems, which currently comprise a digital camera worn externally to capture images and internal components attached to the retina, are likely to reduce in bulkiness and become easier to implant. The miniaturisation of the equipment needed to deliver visual information to the brain via the optic nerve, in combination with improvements in the image quality capable of being delivered, could have a profound effect on those with visual impairments. However, the risk and inconvenience associated with the installation of these systems and the additional capabilities they would have to confer on an individual (e.g. the ability to perceive non-visual light or to see with much greater acuity) would have to advance dramatically before those with unimpaired vision would be likely to adopt these systems to augment their own vision.

Event: Nanodevices utilised within the human body
comment: Researchers have already successfully and safely recharged implanted devices that are smaller than a grain of rice using a wireless method of power transfer. This removes the requirement for bulky batteries and opens up opportunities for implants to become smaller and smaller, and consequently less invasive. This might enable non-surgical routes for the delivery of implants and also increase the number of implants that could be inserted, potentially allowing a whole series of diverse functioning implants to be placed throughout the body.

Event: Implanted drug delivery systems routinely used
comment: The use of implanted systems for delivering drugs from within the human body could lead to a much more efficient and effective use of pharmaceutical agents. This could be widely used in the treatment of those with chronic conditions, who may currently require regular injections or take multiple pills. By incorporating monitoring technologies as well, these devices could provide drugs based on biological feedback, meaning that dosage could be optimised on a highly personalised level.

Event: The grinder community becomes more mainstream
comment: The grinder community (those who conduct invasive biohacking procedures) currently represent a niche element of society. Much of their activity is pioneering but unregulated, and they are broadly regarded as being marginal and even extreme. However, it is possible that these early adopters of body-integrated interfaces could become more mainstream, in the way that other trends such as body piercing have become more prevalent. The popularity of biohacking as an expression of counterculture could see more and more people (particularly within younger demographics) prepared to use this group of technologies.

Event: Implanted devices routinely used in animals
comment: It is possible that implanted devices which track location or monitor body temperature could become used in more expensive pets (particularly dogs and cats) or livestock in order to prevent theft and give an indication of health. This could be driven by trends in pet theft or simply their use being promoted by social media influencers. This practice may see resistance from animal rights campaigners, but this will depend on the perceived benefits to the animals themselves.

Event: Making use of existing common implants
comment: There are currently a large number of prosthetics and devices implanted into the human body for cosmetic and medical purposes. It is possible that such implants might be made much smarter by adding additional electronic components. Dental implants, breast implants or pacemakers could all potentially be augmented in order to collect or relay information from within the human body. This would effectively piggyback on existing surgical processes to install new bio-interfaces. For example pacemakers could collect increasing amounts of information about cardiovascular function or silicone body implants could be fitted with health monitoring sensors.

Event: Licensing and regulation of implant industry
comment: The regulation of implants is likely to be complex. Within the medical domain, existing mechanisms could straightforwardly be extended with the introduction of new expert bodies. However, for more commercial applications in the leisure and entertainment sectors, the public are likely to expect centralised regulation. Their concerns will probably centre on safety and also data security (including reassurance that implanted devices could not be hacked).

Event: Development of a biohacking black market
comment: In the event that the implant industry becomes effectively regulated, it is possible that an unregulated market would spring up for those wishing to bypass restrictions or access more affordable options. This would have implications for enforcement and the monitoring of illegal activities.

Event: Integration of implants into a whole body system
comment: Multiple coordinated sensors could be used all over the body, providing an extensive amount of information about the health of an individual. This could mean that live data about temperature, hydration status, stress related hormone levels, heart rate and blood flow, could be made available to medical professionals or AI processing. This could radically transform the medical diagnostic process, increasing the prediction of health problems and reducing dependency on medical staff charged with routine measurements.

Implantable devices would benefit from embedded AI capabilities to manage and even process some of their potentially large data streams. However, due to size and power restrictions it is likely to have access only to limited resources. So-called ‘Tiny AI’, the effort to reduce the scale of machine learning algorithms such that they can be pushed to smaller edge devices, could be an important development in this context. This in vivo processing could confer benefits such as anonymisation at source and more efficient central data analysis (because only relevant data is transmitted).

It is possible that one of the key functionalities to emerge out of the smart home market is connected security devices that form security systems. These might combine biometrics, image recognition and voice activated passwords to control access to domestic properties and provide security when the residents are away. Similar systems could easily be adapted for use within a defence context.

The development of appliances with genuinely useful functionality and the incorporation of this technology into standard models is likely to increase the adoption of smart devices in the domestic setting. Key factors that could lead to these devices becoming more mainstream, could include the integration of voice commands into domestic appliances and more efficient use of appliances based on automation (e.g. operating overnight without human input). It is possible most new appliances will be manufactured to have some smart features.

The growing use of smart appliances is likely to be reflected in military accommodation. Military families are likely to expect the same supporting infrastructure in their homes as is available in the commercial market. This technology could extend to naval platforms which provide accommodation for their crew. This could help reduce crew sizes by replacing some of the tasks, such as cleaning and cooking, which are currently carried out by humans.

One important factor which is impeding the effectiveness and adoption of smart home devices relates to the lack of interconnectivity and integration for devices from different manufacturers. It is likely in the future that users will want all of their home devices to operate as a coordinated whole. This may be achieved through central hub stations and infrastructure or by the introduction of better compatibility and common standards. The control of this entire system could be achieved through smartphone apps in the first instance, but is more likely to move towards voice control for ease of use.

The potential collection and analysis of so much data from the domestic environment is likely to cause significant concern among the public. There may be calls to specifically regulate the use of this data by the commercial service providers. There will also probably be a drive to ensure very high security of the handling of this information. Obtaining this information would provide hackers with details of people's movements, activities and preferences relating to their home environments, which is likely to increase sensitivity.

Patterns of use are likely to develop rich datasets which can be used to predict future required activity. This could lead devices to be able to anticipate their users needs and start operating accordingly. Functions containing lags, such as house heating, could straightforwardly be learnt by the controlling system. External temperature, time of day, in house activity (e.g. whether moving or not) could all be combined to understand demand and make micro adjustments. In this way, a user's explicit interactions with these devices (e.g. via buttons or dials) may be significantly reduced.

Sensors on smart home devices may be able to gather information about the physical or mental state of their users and adapt their function and activity accordingly. This could be based on a combination of sensors that collect data on the house occupants (e.g. infrared cameras determining the temperature of people). For example, they may appreciate that the user does not want to be bothered by noise because they are concentrating on a task, and moderate their activity accordingly. In combination with predictive analytics, this could lead to smart devices performing seemingly considerate actions, such as putting the kettle on for someone under stress.

One of the key drivers behind adoption of smart home devices could be their ability to manage more efficient energy use, perhaps specifically supporting the use of renewables or off grid power provision (e.g. utilising a house's own solar panels). By understanding patterns of life and anticipating demand, these devices may be able to better schedule and coordinate their activities to manage energy demand optimally within a house, but also across an entire area. Users may have the option to toggle between convenience and energy use optimisation.

Event: Speed and cost of printing reduces significantly
comment: In order for 3D printers or other additive manufacturing equipment to become responsive interfaces, they will need to increase their printing processes dramatically. To enable them to become involved in a dynamic feedback loop with a human user, they could become able to translate a design into an object that could be held within a few seconds or less, and be able to reprint or amend that object based upon human input in the same amount of time. This could allow a machine to deliver information, in the form of an object that can be seen and touched, to a human user, and a human to deliver information back to the machine by communicating changes to the object's design in a rapid way. This would be extremely useful for design and manufacture.

The rapid production of physical objects could be combined with the use of projected 3D imagery to give real solidity to a projected scene. This could mean that models of objects are developed which can be made to look like the real object by projecting imagery over the top. This might be used in contexts such as theatre sets or prototype design.

Rapidly adjusting printed objects could potentially be achieved through integration with other interfaces such as augmented reality or 3D drawing tools (e.g. a stylus). This might enable users to hold an object and signal changes required to its design (e.g. by drawing on it) and then have the object itself adapted (e.g. by laser cutting) or have the object reprinted.

Event: New printing techniques and substrates utilised
comment: Developing techniques (e.g. light polymerised approaches such as continuous liquid interface production) and the development of new substrate materials, if commercialised successfully, could dramatically change the production process and outputs. This could see much faster printing and objects that have much more diverse properties (e.g. elasticity, strength, mass).

It is possible that effective and diverse additive manufacturing tools could be developed that would much better exploit human manipulation. Handheld printing nozzles could become commercially available that allow a user to apply them to a given site with precision and then provide precision printing on that site. This could be similar to a soldering iron or a tattoo pen, except that the highly skilled element of the application would be delivered by a machine. The material itself would also be capable of altering depending on the task.

There are a number of current applications for the printing of organic material, but they are generally expensive, time consuming and require large or expensive equipment. It is possible that these barriers are overcome by advances in technology, design and production methods. From the perspective of interfacing between humans and machines, this could enable humans to receive information in conceptually entirely novel ways. For example, the machine would, in essence, communicate directly with a human's biological processes at the cellular level by printing various organic components. This could see machines involved in profound changes to our bodies and the treatment of diseases.

4D printing, which aims to print objects comprising adaptable materials which respond to different environmental stimuli, could generate a new set of latently reactive interfaces. In this paradigm, the machine would be producing objects that it is anticipating will be shaped by humans in particular ways in the future. This could see the production of materials whose properties and shape could be changed by users depending on their need.

Event: Haptics combined with 3D imagery and AR
comment: Haptic effects are likely to be increasingly integrated with 3D projected imagery and AR, supporting simulated touch sensations for objects occuring within the imagery. This is likely to require the wearing of gloves in the first instance, which are designed to deliver the haptic effects to the hands.

Haptic clothing may be successfully commercialised within the health and wellbeing sector. Clothing which uses different haptic effects (but primarily vibrotactile) could be used to help influence mental state. For example, clothing could use patterns of haptic effect to promote relaxation, aid sleep or increase alertness. The uptake in use of this clothing could come well before any proof of its efficacy, based on successful marketing. There could also be an increase in the use of currently available clothing, which gives haptic feedback on posture for activities such as yoga. Any increase in the market for haptic clothing would probably lead to more developments in capability as competition occurs.

Future generation smartphones could potentially commonly integrate haptic capabilities far in advance of the simple vibrotactile effects seen today. This might include being able to feel the texture of objects on screen, or operate a phone by touch alone based on haptic effects (e.g. to support the visually impaired or a user who is using their visual attention for something else). This has the potential to make touchscreens a bidirectional interface for touch.

Smaller and more practical versions of the haptic exoskeleton gloves currently in development, which apply adjustable levels of resistance to the fingers as they contact virtual objects, could be produced. These devices modulate force as objects are held and squeezed to mimic their hardness. They are currently very bulky in design and relatively unsophisticated in the effect they deliver, but as their design improves and the realism of their mimicry advances, they could become key to allowing a virtual sense of touch.

Event: Haptic bodysuits deployed regularly by the military
comment: Bodysuits integrating a number of haptic effects, could become a standard element of many military personnel's equipment. These suits could utilise haptics as an additional modality for relaying information about hazards, saving it as a channel of communication which is only used in critical situations and which does not get overloaded with other more routine information. Alternatively, it might be used by personnel for more routine tasks (e.g. navigation where users are directed through haptic feedback) to free up visual bandwidth for situational awareness purposes.

Enabling remote operators of robotic equipment to 'feel' what the robot is interacting with, could hugely improve the capability of telerobots. Harnessing human dexterity requires tactile feedback, which research into haptography is seeking to achieve. Incorporating this into telerobotic systems (perhaps through special haptic gloves or a stylus or other tool) could enable much more delicate tasks to be performed effectively by remotely operated robots, such as surgical procedures, technical maintenance or high risk tasks (e.g. bomb disposal).

Interacting with the nervous system to produce direct somatosensory stimulation could create novel effects such as returning the sensation of feeling to individuals with neural damage, or creating phantom sensations in the uninjured. Some advances have already been made in this area, but there are a number of technical and ethical barriers to be overcome first, particularly in a healthy population prepared to use this technology for recreation.

Haptic surfaces could be incorporated into a wide range of equipment to provide virtual tactile cues for physical interaction. For example, rather than having handles for car doors, haptic effects could be used to help users locate the interaction area and perform the necessary action to open the door. This could significantly affect design, by allowing certain objects to be more streamlined for the purposes of style or aerodynamics.

These devices can receive input from other sensors, for example recreating the shape of a human body, dynamically adjusting to the optically sensed movements of an individual. This means that, for example, hand gestures and movements can be recreated using a physical display in a separate location to the user. Objects can also be held in front of sensors and their shape recreated by the display. This is unlikely to have any utility outside of simply providing a physical and visible presence of an individual or object in a different location for the purposes of communication.

Commercial versions of these kinds of dynamic shape displays could be developed, probably for professional settings in the first instance. Within an office context they could be used either to help shape work stations (e.g. providing shape-shifting furniture) or for geospatial design tasks, where a design shape could be shown and then instantly changed based on feedback. Once experienced in the office, this technology could be adopted at home by employees.

Tactile displays could be adopted for use in supporting the medical image examination process by recreating the shape of scanned objects for medical staff, allowing them to feel the output of imaging. This could support better diagnostic performance.

The generation of less bulky displays, could lead to the stage where tablet size and weight devices are available, which provide a tactile display. This could become a braille reading device similar to a Kindle for sighted reading. The device would effectively be able to dynamically render any text in braille for its user. It could even be used with optical character recognition tools to immediately translate written text into braille.

The resolution of these displays could increase significantly if the technology receives funding or interest. The arrays of taxels (physical touchable pixels) are currently fairly low resolution (at highest extending only into the hundreds).
