It is possible that the size of these taxels could reduce and their number could increase, creating much more granular tactile surfaces.

Event: Tactile displays utilised by the VR community
comment: These types of displays might be used on a larger scale within the VR community in order to dynamically produce real world physical representations of virtual objects or surfaces. They could be integrated with VR rigs to provide users with a touch panel that enables them to feel in the environment.

The use of tactile displays could be incorporated into smart home devices to make them capable of presenting braille to visually impaired users, substituting the use of visual displays for presenting information about their function. These displays would first have to be miniaturised and then made substantially cheaper in order to facilitate this.

The trend towards human-centric design and technology for lighting in work and living spaces is likely to increase. This could involve better uses of light to match occupancy and movement around a space, using sensors and data analytics to optimise efficiency and visibility. It might also involve matching lighting to external brightness or even the circadian rhythm of occupants. These systems might even enable external lighting across large spaces to be coordinated and matched to human patterns of use (e.g. across a city to support road safety or reduce crime). Underpinning all of this would need to be the development of a much more digital lighting infrastructure.

Event: AI helps deliver mood dependent lighting
comment: As the understanding of interpreting mood state based on sensor data increases, it is possible that lighting systems could be developed which detect users' moods and respond with lighting settings which match or influence those moods. This could be used to help boost wellbeing or productivity.

Traffic lights may adapt to provide much more flexible and intelligent traffic management support. This could involve improved responsiveness to traffic conditions based on what the light itself can sense (perhaps using image recognition cameras or pollution detection) as well as the receipt of external signals and some predictive capabilities (e.g. using data sent by networked vehicles to understand what is about to happen at a junction). In addition to their main function, traffic lights could also take on additional functions such as displaying the speeds of passing vehicles in an attempt to influence speed reduction or display information about road conditions. As vehicles move towards greater automation, the use of light as a visual signal to drivers could be eliminated altogether.

Event: Lasers used more commonly used and LEDs improve
comment: Lasers produce more light than LEDs and consume less electricity. This may drive more common application of laser lighting (for example, they are already being integrated into some car headlights. This could mean greater illumination, clarity and penetration of light in a range of conditions (night, fog, etc.). Additionally, LEDs themselves are improving dramatically, and gains in efficiency and light output are likely to occur. Reduced costs for all types of lighting could mean that many everyday objects could be fitted with lighting (e.g. receptacles that show whether they are full or hot based on a light display which is triggered by given sensors).

The effect of light on mental wellbeing is becoming increasingly well understood. It might be that such therapy develops into a useful and important tool in the treatment of mental health. In this case, individuals may have their own lighting interfaces which they use to regulate their mental state. Commercial providers could begin to produce specific devices, or this functionality could be integrated into other common devices.

Event: Improved power supply technology for portable lights
comment: Improvements in solar packs and battery technologies may increase the mobility of lighting systems by becoming smaller and lighter, and also by extending their charge duration. Advances in low energy lighting would also support this trend. This could mean that the use of light to communicate information to people could be extended into places where this is currently not practical. For example, being used as enduring warning signals in maritime or mountainous environments.

Materials such as moldable silicone, which is robust, flexible but has many of the positive optical properties of glass, are likely to be increasingly used to develop more robust, pliable and clear lights. Also filters such as dichroic films could be developed further to allow more sophisticated and potentially controllable optical effects. It is possible developments in materials could lead to lights being used in environments or with devices that are not currently possible. For example, very thin pliable sheets of lighting could be developed inexpensively and possibly incorporated into clothing, enabling garments to be illuminated or more subtly altering their colour.

The materials required to produce bendable and foldable displays could overcome some of the key manufacturing and production challenges that currently prevent these technologies from being rolled out in a practical and commercially viable way for devices. This would lead to high quality, larger 2D display screens that would be much easier to transport and would be more physically robust.

Event: Tiny projectors begin to replace screens
comment: Miniaturisation of projector technology could see high quality projected screens delivered via small handheld devices (or even wearables). The technical difficulties in projecting onto rough or uneven surfaces could also be overcome, allowing projected touchscreens to be rendered onto any wall, table or even body surface (e.g. the back of the hand).

Event: Irregular surface projection used for domestic decoration
comment: Smart wallpaper and other similar developments could become a part of modern domestic environments, enabling decoration to be modulated at the press of a button. This could support the regulation of internal environments to help influence mood.

2D displays that can be built into transparent surfaces (such as internal or external windows) may become straightforward and cost effective to manufacture. These screens would be opaque when on display, but transparent when turned off. This would support a number of new opportunities for delivering visual content (e.g. in vehicles, offices and commercial properties),

Advances in autonomous driving technologies may reach a stage where restrictions against using visual displays while nominally in control of a vehicle are amended to reflect a new reality. In this scenario the use of 2D visual displays for issuing commands to vehicles or even for infotainment purposes may be permitted.

The ability to project images onto irregular surfaces in a dynamic and intelligent way could be mastered, making digital camouflage a practical capability that can be deployed to make objects difficult to see against any backdrop. The size and robustness of the equipment required to project images in this way could improve dramatically to enable this capability to be deployed, even in harsh environments.

The use of rigid flat 2D screens might reduce significantly, as their dimensional inflexibility and bulkiness become seen as unnecessary and severely limiting. Televisions and computer monitors might no longer be fixtures in every professional and domestic setting. They could be replaced by a variety of alternatives, primarily projected screens.

Basic projectors capable of displaying 3D holograms, either via the use of a glass surface or projecting the image into open space, could be produced for a commercial market at affordable prices. They might be marketed as entertainment devices and could stimulate a boom in specific media (such as 3D films or 3D gaming). Initial devices would probably be quite limited in their capabilities, projecting into a small space and requiring a set viewing angle. However, if the medium becomes popular, this would rapidly drive developments and the sophistication of these devices could increase quickly.

The ability to produce realistic holograms in shared spaces could become sufficient to enable a flourishing of art based on 3D images. These images would move beyond the Pepper's Ghost illusion that is currently used in stage shows, where the image is projected onto a reflective surface. This would allow the images to be viewed from any angle. In the first instance the imagery might be static and used within the set for the staging of live performances, but soon plays or musical performances where the performers are not physically present, could become commonplace.

Event: Integration of 3D imagery with real world objects
comment: Real world objects or interfaces could be incorporated into 3D imagery, providing solidity to the image. For example, 3D images could be projected into real spaces (e.g. historical sites). They could be projected on top of buildings or specially built facades, to allow people to feel static 3D projections. Alternatively, devices such as exercise ergometers could have 3D imagery projected around them to provide the illusion of travel (e.g. cycling through an environment within a peloton).

Holograms could become a routine element of teleconferencing, allowing people to see 3D images of the person and even the environment they are remotely connected to. This could enable much richer visual information to be presented. This might enable much more informative visual inspections of people (e.g. in medical consultations) and objects (e.g. allowing a technician to give better remote advice).

3D images could become a central part of military planning or maintaining situational awareness. 3D terrain maps, potentially with dynamic assets moving around them, could be projected into operational HQs to keep commanders and their staff apprised of the situation. This could add information value by allowing users to easily see height and depth within the operational environment.

Event: Sophisticated holograms used in fraud and security
comment: The technical difficulty in generating physical holograms means that they are already used in fraud prevention for financial and identity documents or artefacts (e.g. passports and bank cards). As the technology develops and techniques get cheaper, it is possible that increasingly sophisticated holograms could feature in the process of, say, verifying an individual's identity.
It is possible that the ability to generate 3D projected imagery could be delivered by small devices, such as smartwatches, supporting the portable delivery of small images.

Techniques such as acoustic levitation could be perfected, enabling users to experience the illusion of touch to be incorporated into 3D projected images. These techniques are likely to only deliver a very superficial haptic effect, but when combined with realistic imagery, it could seem quite spectacular.

Projected 3D imagery could be used to project the outputs of data analytics into a work space. This may enable users to move around data, view it from different angles and analyse it in a more collaborative way.

Eye tracking is already being integrated with VR headset technology to provide effects such as foveated rendering, which enables more efficient use of available processing power to concentrate on delivering high quality images to the elements of the virtual world which are being looked at by the user. Eye tracking technology is likely to be more successfully commercially utilised in headsets in the future. This would also improve user experience for dynamic activities and social interactions. For example, it would better support hand eye coordination tasks and allow individuals within a virtual experience to establish natural eye contact.

One of the key limitations of VR headsets is the bulkiness of the equipment and its lack of comfort. There is a strong commercial drive to make headsets lighter and more comfortable. The use of holographic optics and other advanced techniques could lead to the development of lightweight glasses that are able to deliver an immersive VR optical experience. In combination with earplugs, these could allow a highly mobile and comfortable interface.

Event: High performance wireless headsets become standard
comment: Wireless headsets currently have some issues relating to connectivity and refresh rates. The expansion of 5G infrastructure and the advance of processing techniques are likely to remove most barriers to high performance wireless VR headsets. This could extend the mobility of their use, allowing people potentially to use VR in almost any environment (provided they are in a physically safe space to do so).

Features such as the field of view, the resolution and frame rates will gradually increase to the extent where VR headsets would be able to deliver a full field of view (i.e. without a narrow range of vision) to a level of resolution and with frame rate that matches vision of the real world. The quality of the graphics themselves will also inevitably improve, such that seeing a VR environment could become indistinguishable from looking at reality.

Contact lenses capable of projecting high quality images could be developed and begin to replace or act as an alternative for glasses or headsets. This could extend the portability of VR and make the experience more immersive as the image would appear closer to the eye.

It is possible that the quality of the visual and audio experience delivered by VR headsets could reach a stage that means that experiences within a virtual environment become capable of traumatising users. Violent games or military simulations could begin to represent a hazard to users.

The cost of lightweight VR glasses or headsets could reduce substantially which would enable the technology to move beyond its current niche status and become much more mainstream. The availability of cheap, comfortable and easy to use VR equipment would probably drive increased adoption.

The quality of immersive experience delivered by VR headsets could become sufficiently high that it supports the use of VR as a means of treating PTSD, through enabling sufferers to revisit environments and experiences associated with trauma as part of the treatment process.

Event: Increased integration with device based AR
comment: There are likely to be developments in the modelling and processing underpinning AR systems which allow the coordinated synchronisation of multiple sets of AR glasses with those experiencing AR via device screens (e.g. tablets or phones). This will enable multiple individuals to have the same AR experience from different angles and through different interfaces, effectively creating a shared augmented world.

Event: Visual range and perspective delivered in AR
comment: AR glasses will probably be able to accurately track where a user is looking in the physical world and deliver augmented objects into this space in a way which completely replicates 'real' perspective and distance. This could allow the range of AR to be significantly extended, where objects can be seamlessly rendered into the background and foreground, and realistically move between the two simulating appropriate speeds. This would transform AR from a technology which currently delivers objects into the near distance, to one which could transform your entire field of view, creating simulated backgrounds (e.g. natural features or conurbations) and objects moving over long distances (e.g. vehicles).

Event: Handheld controls for AR widely used
comment: Handheld control devices could become an integral part of the AR experience, allowing users to interact with the augmented elements of AR. These wand-like devices may be similar to the hand controllers used in VR environments, or they could be similar to a mouse. They would allow users to move or stimulate augmented objects they are viewing through their glasses, and even deliver augmented effects into the view (e.g. shooting a laser).

Event: Acceptability of glasses mounted cameras adressed
comment: Resolving this issue will be critical to enabling AR experiences that are able to fully integrate and respond to the real world. It is possible that this will be legally and ethically resolved in many countries to the extent that using cameras to support certain applications (e.g. AR games) will be widely accepted by the public. This may require limits on the way information is collected and analysed for individuals who stray into the AR view without providing any consent.

AR glasses which are indistinguishable from normal prescription glasses or sunglasses are likely to be developed. This could lead to greater adoption of smart glasses, as they come to be seen as a lightweight and acceptable fashion accessory, rather than a geeky piece of tech. This could pose a number of privacy and social interaction issues, as it becomes difficult to determine if someone is using AR or not (potentially receiving data about people with whom they are meeting).

Event: AR becomes integral to everyday life
comment: It is possible that the use of AR glasses becomes as integral a part of everyday life as is the use of smartphones. This could mean that individuals wear their glasses or have them to hand for most periods of the day, and consume content (e.g. games, directions, advertising, news) within many different settings (commuting, in the office and at home for entertainment). The widespread use of such an immersive technology could have profound impacts on the way the world around us is designed.

5G (as well as edge computing) infrastructure could develop sufficiently to enable the delivery of high quality and ubiquitous AR services to users via their glasses. Users may be provided with reliable and uninterrupted access to AR in most pockets of the developed world. This would support AR's use for many more services and in a wider set of contexts than is currently possible.

Event: AR glasses fully adopted by dismounted personnel
comment: Trials and experiments currently being conducted with Western military forces could translate into the development of AR glasses that are capable of being used effectively in an operational military setting by a large number of dismounted personnel. A number of issues to do with the user experience, attentional focus, the reliability of service provision and the development of the right supporting software and services will need to be addressed first. This could see most dismounted personnel in receipt of visual information (e.g. directions, data about an environment, etc.) while they perform their duties.

Haptic technologies, such as haptic suits and gloves, could be integrated with the use of AR glasses to deliver multisensory AR experiences, where individuals can feel some of the augmented environment and its objects. This would help generate even more immersive AR environments.

The sophistication of the delivery of sound via smart headphones may increase, such that devices are able to accurately measure hearing and deliver sound to optimise a wide range of listening experiences for the individual user.

Devices which are worn close to the ear, but do not block it, could be developed to allow the external world to be heard and its natural sound to be augmented by synthetic sound. These devices would be used with other technologies to deliver augmented reality experiences, such as listening to music privately while still being able to hold a conversation with someone in the real world.
Legislation limiting the use of long range acoustic devices for the dispersal of crowds may be introduced, severely curtailing their use in law enforcement and defence in many countries.

Surgical procedures and the devices themselves are likely to develop to an extent that means inserting a cochlear implant becomes much less traumatic. The quality of their detection and relay of environmental sound, in some cases, could become comparable to a natural cochlear. This may have a dramatic effect on hearing impairment.

Event: Use of ear implants among non-hearing impaired becomes common
comment: Ear implants could be developed to enhance hearing, allowing humans to hear sounds that are currently inaudible, both in terms of pitch and volume. These may possibly be adopted by those without hearing impairments as a move towards transhumanism. The devices would be able to be modulated so that they can be turned on and off and various capabilities could be used in different situations. This would open up new ways to experience the world around us.

Event: Noise cancellating headphones get cheaper and smaller
comment: Active noise cancelling headphones are likely to start being manufactured for much lower prices and become less bulky, leading to rapid increases in market share for the headphone market.

Sound might be used as part of a smart home system to positively modulate the mood of residents. The system would be able to sense mood using various approaches based on image recognition and other indicators, and learns to deliver sounds to reduce stress or invigorate an individual in an intuitive way.

3D audio could become the standard way of delivering sound to listeners using most devices. Most new music could begin to be recorded using 3D sound techniques, becoming a central part of the production and artistic process. All devices would then start to be developed to better deliver 3D sound and 3D headphones would become standard.

It is likely that BCI implants will become less inherently invasive (e.g. removing the need for wires passing through the skull or solving some of the issues related to stimulating immune responses) and that the surgical procedures to position the implant will concomitantly improve. This may make the process of obtaining an implant much less risky and more commercially viable.

A combination of improvements in the understanding of brain function, signal processing capabilities and advanced data analytic techniques (drawing on new machine learning approaches) could lead to dramatic leaps in the ability to decode the brain's neural activity. In the first instance, this might enable BCIs to reliably and accurately interpret physical and mental actions in a wide number of settings.

A cleverly marketed and stylishly designed non-invasive BCI might become a trailblazer for this interface (in a similar way as occurred with Fitbits and smartwatches). This could see a dramatic increase in both public awareness and usage of BCIs. Their growth in the user community would be likely to stimulate associated services for these BCIs. Other developers would be likely to try and mimic the device developed by any early market leader.

If there were growth in the ownership of BCIs, there would also be a growth in the number of applications available to exploit this technology (as has been seen with the growth in VR gaming and the release of latest generation VR headsets). In addition to gaming, there might also be a number of applications that use input from BCIs to deliver services (in the same fashion as smart speakers have seen an increasing number of voice controlled personal assistant services). These services could range from the control of domestic appliances and environments, to ways of selecting options presented via a visual screen (e.g. selecting TV content to watch without a remote control). The fidelity of the input is likely to be insufficient to enable complex and detailed commands to be relayed.

Disabilities associated with certain neurological conditions (e.g. those based on trauma to the spinal cord) may be effectively overcome by improved BCI sensors and processing, combined with embedded devices which bypass the sites of any neural damage. Paralysis of this kind could be effectively eradicated.

Event: BCI implants used more widely by general population
comment: The general public may become more willing to have BCI implants if the process becomes sufficiently safe, convenient and affordable. It could start to be perceived in the same way that laser eye surgery or even tattooing is currently seen. A greater uptake of BCI implants might open up a number of applications for human-to-human interactions. It is possible that implanted BCIs could be viewed as an accepted, and even obvious upgrade to commercially available non-invasive BCIs.

Event: Issues arise relating to BCI data privacy
comment: The public are likely to become conscious of the privacy issues surrounding the use of BCIs, which may be portrayed by the media as being able to read minds and then relay this data to service providers. There is therefore likely to be a push to tightly regulate how this information can be stored, shared and analysed by companies handling BCI derived data. This could take the form of legislation resembling the way biometric data is treated in many cases. A single example of misuse of this data could have a dramatic impact on public perceptions and willingness to adopt the technology.

Event: The boundaries of mental agency are blurred
comment: AI analysis and interpretation of BCI derived data could develop to an extent that extends far beyond capturing of motor signals or enabling simple option selection. This could effectively lead to a much greater capacity to 'read' human thought. This might open up opportunities relating to interpreting complex patterns of thought, such as intent and desire, and relaying these to machines. This would pose significant challenges to our existing concepts of mental agency, where machines might be instructed to do things based on something other than conscious thought.

Event: BCIs used to treat mental illness
comment: BCIs could be used in the treatment of mental illness by stimulating certain parts of the brain (e.g. the reward centre) in response to changes in mood state, which are in turn detected by a BCI. This could be important for conditions such as depression, and might be the beginning of technologies which support bi-directional information flows.

It is possible that effective bi-directional systems could be developed, which allow targeted stimulation of parts of the brain. This could lead to the ability to generate non-volitional movements that are as responsive and precise as our volitional movements, allowing a human body to effectively be controlled. It could even allow brain activity to be regulated in some ways, and maybe even generate patterns of thought, although there are a large number of challenges to overcome before this would be possible.

Event: Neural lace for humans successfully used
comment: Neural lace, a thin mesh like material which is injected into the brain and physically integrates directly with neurons, even adapting to changes within the brain, could be successfully trialled with human users. This technology would allow a much greater surface area of connectivity and has the potential to revolutionise the capabilities that BCIs could support. For example, it may be possible for human memory to be augmented by digital storage. It would also be a much less invasive procedure than surgical implants, which could increase adoption.

Event: Commercial availability of rudimentary olfactory interfaces
comment: Initial devices could be launched onto the market which meet niche or novelty requirements (e.g. to support immersive gaming or in support of art or museum installations). These devices would raise public awareness of the possibilities available to interfaces utilising the sense of smell.

Event: Research into digital delivery of smell conducted
comment: An increasing body of research into the impact of smell on factors such as mood and memory, could uncover more powerful ways to affect emotion and cognition through manipulating smell. This may drive more funding into research to develop devices which could deliver smell to users in order to exploit these effects.

Technologies designed to synthetically produce scents could be developed and minitiarised to an extent which makes wearable olfactory interfaces a practical option. These interfaces might mix different ingredients to deliver a palette of scents to users. The delivery directly to nostrils could reduce the amounts of chemical components required.

Digitally controlled domestic environments may start to routinely include the use of scent manipulation to create optimal environments for inhabitants. This might include intelligent, adaptive features such as responding to the mood or alertness of the inhabitants. This could involve relaxing inhabitants at times of stress or supporting sleep or wakefulness through smell.

Equipment could begin to incorporate synthetic scent production to support human technician diagnosis. For example, equipment which is faulty could emit a particular smell to indicate a given fault. Augmenting smell could also become an available capability. For instance, introducing synthetic scents during an eating experience which amplifies the food's natural smell.

Event: Smell used with sensory impaired individuals
comment: Scent could be used to relay information about the environment to individuals with hearing or visual impairment, which would otherwise be sensed by seeing or hearing. For example, the occurrence of a small fire in one place might lead to the delivery of the smell of burning to a building occupant with sensory impairment instead of a fire alarm.

In order to generate more immersive virtual environments, olfactory interfaces could become a key part of the equipment used to build these worlds. VR users may come to expect their virtual environments to deliver smell in a natural way (i.e. where directionality and intensity help to determine where the smell is coming from). These effects may be achieved through larger scent producing units, but it is more likely they will need to be delivered via person-borne interfaces, in order to overcome the problems that would be experienced in trying to dissipate scent if it were released into the room at large.
